title: Angry Barclays customers should quit the bank over cash row
text:
Angry Barclays customers who want to continue getting cash at their local post office should vote with their feet and switch bank, a minister has said.

The row over the Barclays cash scandal deepened as City minister John Glen became the fourth Government minister to wade in.

He said that customers are free to leave the bank whose decision is purely commercial and aimed at saving £7million per year.

More than 15million cash withdrawals were carried out by the bank’s customers at post offices last year. It is thought the decision to axe the transactions will save Barclays just £7million a year

It is more than two weeks since Barclays announced a ban on customers withdrawing their savings at the Post Office.

Many customers have threatened to quit the bank unless bosses reverse the decision but the bank, which claims none of its customers will be left without access to cash, has refused to change policy.

Yesterday it emerged that Barclays had lost 80,000 current accounts in the year to June, with only Halifax shedding more. Mr Glen, replying to a written Commons question from Lib Dem MP Jane Dodds, said: ‘If Barclays customers value withdrawing cash over the counter using the Post Office, they may wish to consider switching to an alternative bank.

He added: ‘Customers are more able than ever to hold their banks to account by voting with their feet, and that banks are incentivised to work hard to retain their existing customers and attract new ones.’

His comments follow private interventions from the Business Secretary Andrea Leadsom and Post Office minister Kelly Tolhurst with Barclays executives.

Lord Duncan, a minister in the business department, said earlier this week the bank had been told in ‘words of only one syllable’ that its behaviour was unacceptable.

More than 120 MPs accused it of abandoning vulnerable customers and adding to the cash crisis.

Business secretary Andrea Leadsom, pictured, is one of four ministers to have criticised Barclays bank after the firm announced it was no longer going to allow customers to withdraw cash from the Post Office

This newspaper has also received scores of emails and letters of protest, and close to 19,000 customers have signed an online petition demanding a Barclays U-turn.

Last night more customers said they plan to desert the bank. Kathy Wilkinson, from Gloucester, said: ‘Post offices are crucial to the social fabric of small communities and villages. I will be closing my account which I have held with Barclays for some 30 years if this goes ahead.’ Tomorrow Barclays is expected to report three-month profits of £17million a day. Last year the chief executive Jes Staley’s £3.4million pay packet was boosted by cutting costs.

The bank has closed around 490 branches over five years. More than 15million cash withdrawals were carried out by the bank’s customers at post offices in 2018.

Barclays will set up 300 ‘pop-up banking pods’ and cashback arrangements with 200 local businesses to curb the impact of its decision.
